photo.description: Friday 14 August: This morning is our first view of the statue. Having had such an intimate relationship with it over the last few weeks it is fantastic to see it as the sculptor intended, from the ground and at a distance. photo.description: On the east side of Westminster's Old Palace Yard is this bronze statue of King Richard I (reign 1189 - 1199). Made in 1860 by Baron Carlo Marochetti. He was known as Richard the Lionheart and Coeur de Lion (as is inscribed on the plinth) even before he became king, because of his reputation as a military leader and warrior. It is Grade II listed. The statue of Richard I is outside the House of Lords. statue of Richard I - Heritage Gateway Westminster Palace- World Heritage Site

photo.description: Bronze statue of Richard the Lionheart (1860) which stands in Old Palace Yard alongside the Houses the Parliament. While the overall effect of Richard seated on this horse with sword brandished aloft is quite heroic, it was said in the Art Journal at the time it was erected that it was 'a fine statue, but one which is so entirely unfinished that we should never regard it otherwise than as a sketch'. This may indeed have been illusion to the fact that an earlier, and more finished, version of this statue by Carlo Marochetti (1805-1867) stood outside the entrance to the Great Exhibition of 1851 in Hyde Park. Certainly its current surroundings, in what is now the House of Lords' car park, does it no favours.

photo.description: When the statue was cast it was made in a large number of small pieces which then had to be joined together, around the steel armature. Roman joints would have been used widely. The two elements to be joined would have been overlapped and holes drilled through the two layers. Cone-shaped bronze plugs would have been inserted into the holes and hammered in. The two sheets would have drawn tighter and tighter together and once they could be hammered in no further, any excess plugs would have been cut off and the joint smoothed over. You can see the line of plug ends and the joint here on the horse’s flank. This image is subject to parliamentary copyright. www.parliament.uk/

photo.description: The bent sword is clearly visible. The archive file has lengthy correspondence about the damage and reveals that some people were in favour of not repairing it but keeping the damage as a symbol of Britain ‘bent but not broken’. However this idea seems to have lost favour and, in April 1947, the Parliamentary District Surveyor reported that the sword had been ‘visibly straightened by a recent high winds’ which indicates how wobbly and insecure it was. By early May that year the danger had been recognised and the Superintendent of Works reported the ‘sword had been removed for safety and is stored at the Horse Guards’. It was finally repaired and reinstated in June 1948. Crown copyright images reproduced by permission of The National Archives

photo.description: On 26 September 1940 a high explosive bomb fell in Old Palace Yard causing severe damage to the building. The report of the incident says ‘the statue of Richard Coeur de Lion appears to have been lifted bodily from the pedestal but sustained only minor damage, the sword being bent.’ The survival of the statue was the subject of an allied wartime radio broadcast in 1940 as a symbol of the strength of democracy which would bend but not break under attack. For more information on the Second World War damage to the Palace of Westminster see the bomb damage section on the Living Heritage site. This image is subject to parliamentary copyright. www.parliament.uk/

photo.description: Bronze statue of Richard the Lionheart (1860) which stands in Old Palace Yard alongside the Houses the Parliament. While the overall effect of Richard seated on this horse with sword brandished aloft is quite heroic, it was said in the Art Journal at the time it was erected that it was 'a fine statue, but one which is so entirely unfinished that we should never regard it otherwise than as a sketch'. This may indeed have been illusion to the fact that an earlier, and more finished, version of this statue by Carlo Marochetti (1805-1867) stood outside the entrance to the Great Exhibition of 1851 in Hyde Park. Certainly its current surroundings, in what is now the House of Lords' car park, does it no favours.
